thread.title_full: It's not just you - robots are rubbish at building Ikea furniture too

author: Sophie Curtis
title: It's not just you - robots are rubbish at building Ikea furniture too
text:
Comments 
Robots may be taking over our jobs , our cars and even our sex lives , but there is one area where they are still no match for humans – assembling flatpack furniture. 
While robots excel at simple, linear tasks – such as picking up and placing objects in fixed positions, welding, and painting – they to struggle to cope in messy, cluttered environments where objects are arranged in a haphazard fashion. 
However, researchers at Nanyang Technological University in Singapore are developing a robot that they claim could one day be capable of assembling small parts in an "unstructured environment". 
In order to test their robot, the researchers, Francisco Suarez-Ruiz and Quang-Cuong Pham, gave it the task of assembling an Ikea chair. 
(YouTube / CRI Group @ NTU) 
The robot consists of two arms capable of six-axis motion, each equipped with parallel grippers to pick up objects. The grippers have force sensors to determine how strongly they are gripping, and a six-camera vision system with a positional accuracy of around 3mm. 
The task was broken down into various sub tasks, one of which was inserting a dowel into a hole in a stick of wood – a task that most humans would find easy. 
(YouTube / CRI Group @ NTU) 
As the video shows, the robot has to go through a pre-programmed sequence of motions to map out the shape of the surface and its edges, before pushing the dowel gently against the surface until it enters the hole. 
The whole process essentially amounts to a system of trial-and-error, and takes significantly longer than an average human performing the same task. 
The researchers said that, while tremendous progress has been made in 3D perception for robots in recent years, current 3D-vision systems are still not precise enough for fine assembly. 
(YouTube / CRI Group @ NTU) 
While this may come as a disappointment to anyone who has spent hours weeping over Ikea's cryptic picture instructions, those who are worried about the "rise of the machines" can rest assured that some tasks are still beyond the scope of artificial intelligence. 
This is not the first time someone has attempted to build a robot capable of assembling Ikea furniture. In 2013, researchers from MIT demonstrated how a tag team of Kuka youBots could assemble an Ikea table.
